3ishop Has De!ivered Series of Fifteen
Lectures in the United
States

"It is daily being proved that
there is hope for the world only
in the Christian gospel," said the
Rt.. Rev. Joseph A. Ingram, Lord
Bishop of London, in his talk to
the various student bodies of the
city at the Lyric Theater last
Thursday afternoon This is the
fifteenth of a series of lectures delivered to student bodies by the
Lord Bishop in his tour of the
United States.

Christianity True Religion

"Why am I a Christian ?" the
Lord Bishop asked, "partly because I was born one; but chiefly
because I know it to be the only
true religion. However, everyone must be a Columbus and discover the continent of his own
soul." The Lord Bishop then
went on to say that when one is
seized with the conviction of the
righteousness of religion, he will
work unceasingly to do good in
the world, and he will be happy.
He spoke of his own life, which is
filled from morning to night with
work yet, knowing that it is for
the proper cause, he is happy. No
one, he pointed out, should be
content. Everyone should try to
make himself and the world better
and more pleasing to God.

In Another Way Out, the play
coached by Rodgers., Milton Robinson will play the leading male
role. Judson Dimling will play
the female lead opposite him.
These men are showing up very
well in the rehearsals held so far.
Moore, Schuster, and Smith will
act in the remaining parts.

Hopkins'-Fifth Game
May Not Be Held
Because of the 'financial loss incurred in the promoting of last
year's Hopkins-Fifth Regiment
games, it is very doubtful whether
the University athletic authorities
will participate in the meet this
year.
Last year the armory contest
was a complete ,financial failure,
due to the total lack of support
from either the local sporting public or the Hopkins undergraduate
body. Thirteen colleges, twentyseven high schools and nine athletic clubs participated. Charlie
Hoff, the Norwegian star, Willie
Plant and Herb Myer were booked
as feature stars.
In place of the usual HopkinsFifth Regiment games there is a
possibility that an interscholastic
meet will be sponsored by the Jay
athletic authorities. The armory
would be used for the event but
no connection will exist between
the Hopkins and the Fifth Regiment athletic departments.

PATCHED SYRACUSE TEAM
SLIDES THROUGH MUD TO
31-0 VICTORY OVER JAYS
Blue Team Is Shifted—Kaplan and Ciscle in Lineup

JONES STARS FOR ORANGE
Second String End Gains 250 Yards
and Scores Three Touchdowns

A revamped Hopkins eleven
fought back to a revamped Syracuse team on the New Yorkers'
field, and made a highly creditable
showing last Saturday. The score
was 31-0.
Syracuse, with eight men on
the injured list, used many substitutes. The Jay team was also
shifted from last week's list.
New Jay Lineup

Kaplan took the place of Pin dell
in the backfield and Ciscle replaced
Strader at center. Jackson was
substituted for Lyons when the
latter suflered what was at first
feared to be a serious concussion
of the brain. Graduate Manager
Keyes declared that "Bobby" was
all right late Sunday night.
Jones Orange Star

The most brilliant player in the
game was Jones, Orange signal
caller, who was promoted from
second string end. Jones gained
a total of over 250 yards himself
and scored three touchdowns. At
the start of the second half he ran
the ball back 80 yards from kickoff for a touchdown.
Although Syracuse scored 12
points in the first period of each
half, the Jays showed their fight
by holding them in the second and
fourth quarters. The Orange was
held scoreless in the second frame
GWINN FIRST BUT JAYS
LOSE BY ONE POINT while they scored once in the last
period.

In spite of the fact that Dick
Gwinn, captain of the track team,
walked off with first place in the
cross country rnn with University
of Maryland last Saturday, johns
Hopkins came out on the long
end of a 27 to 28 score, with the
scoring system being arranged so
that the first five men on each
team counted, and the team with
the lowest score was the winner.
Eighteen men started, nine for
Hopkins, nine for Maryland, and
Gwinn crossed the finish line
thirty-four minutes after the start,
being about a quarter of a mile
ahead of Neunan, captain of
Maryland's team, who placed second. Neuman set a fast pace at
the beginning of the race and kept
the lead for about a mile and a
quarter, when Gwinn passed him.
From then on the Hopkins captain was not hard pressed and he
finished with plenty of reserve
strength. Schiebel was pressed
pretty closely by Hill, but on the
backstretch and the straightaway
the Blue Jay runner drew steadily
away, so that he finished about
fifteen yards ahead of the Black
and Gold man.

JAMAICAN EXPEDITION YIELDS
MUCH MATERIAL FOR STUDY
In the Botanical Laboratories in
Gilman Hall three graduate students and the head of the department are still busy studying specimens of tropical flora brought
back from Jamaica as the result
of a scientific expedition there last
summer.
The expedition included members of the Department of Botany
at the johns Hopkins as well as
several noted botanists from other
institutions. The party was led
by Dr. Duncan S. Johnson, head
of the Department of Botany at
Hopkins. Dr. W. R. Maxon, fern
specialist at the Smithsonian Museum in Washington, a member
of the expedition, collected some
two thousand specimens of ferns

COTILLION TO BE HELD
NOVEMBER 13
The Cotillion Club will
hold its first formal dance in
the ballroom of the Belvedere Hotel, Saturday, November 13, •the night of the
St. John's-Hopkins football
game. The Blue Jay Orchestra will probably furnish the
music. Admission will be
three dollars for couples, two
dollars for stags. Tickets
may be purchased from
members of the Cotillion
Club.

PRICE,5 CENTS

Hopkins Kicks Often

The Blue team did little ball
carrying, kicking back on the secoFtd or third down. Since the ball
was soggy and the field slippery,
the Yellowjackets were unable to
run the ball back far. A pleasant
surprise was accorded Dr. Van
Orman in Jackson's kicking.
When Lyons was taken out because of his injury, Jackson, who
replaced him, did the booting and
performed very creditably.
Boynton played an excellent defensive game throughout the contest. In the fourth quarter when
Syracuse had only two feet to go
for a first down, he broke through
and got the man behind the line
with an exceptionally hard and effective tackle.

IS THE OLD FIGHT PASSING?
A few weeks ago, the NEWS-LETTER commented editorially
upon the lack of spirit at football games. At that time the year
had just begun, freshmen were absolutely green, and upper classmen had not yet got back in the traces. It was only natural that
during the first week all types of organization should be at sixes
and sevens. We contented ourselves, therefore, with simply calling attention to the poor spirit, since in the past such

a

comment,

coupled with the settling influence exerted by the passage of a
week or two, has always been all that was necessary to set things
going right.
This year we were wrong; it has not been sufficient. Three
home games have been played. At no time have more than four
hundred and fifty students been present; out of the eight hundred
only slightly more than six hundred have procured their Athletic
Association tickets.
Support of the team, especially as evidenced by cheering at
games, has lagged all year; and in the Loyola game, when it was
needed most, it reached its lowest ebb.

While the eleven was

sliding around in the mud, fighting its hardest against an opponent of totally unexpected strength, what support did it get
from the stands?

Not much. The cheering section, small as

it is, was not completely filled. Those who were there, huddled
around a hurriedly summoned remnant of the band, save for a
few yells which were not any too good, sat in dejected silence.
That was not an inspiring sight to the men on the field, who were
doing their best and taking a bad beating in the bargain; nor
was it encouraging to any of those interested in football at Hopkins.
"Playing the game for the game's sake," and not "a winner
at any cost," may be only poses at some institutions. At Hopkins this spirit has been genuine, and in it lies the strength and
value of athletics at the University. An incident like the spirit
at the Loyola game may be an indication that the old Hopkins
standards of amateurism and sturdy support are changing. We
hope, however, that it was only an accident, springing from some
other cause.
Three more home games, including the two biggest, remain.
At these three games we will have a chance to see whether or not
the old Hopkins fight is passing.

Dr. French Picks
Frosh Debaters
At a meeting of the candidates
for the freshman debating team
on last Wednesday, Dr. French
picked the men who will represent
the class in the annual FreshmanSophomore Debate.
Dr. French's selections were
based on the quality of speeches
that each candidate prepared on
either side of the question, "Resolved, That the non-athletic activities in American colleges constitute an unwise use of the student's time."
There was an exceedingly poor
representation—only four members of the class being present.
The team finally chosen consisted
of Milton Blumenfeld, chairman,
Paul Spear, Paul Cordish, and
Leroy London, alternate.

LELAND STANFORD ADOPTS NEW
PLAN IN MODIFIED FORM
Leland-Stanford University has
decided to follow the lead of
Johns Hopkins and do away with
the first two years of undergraduate work. Dean Ames, in commenting on this step, said that the
Leland-Stanford plan would differ
from Johns Hopkins' in that Leland-Stanford does not plan to
make a graduate university out of
their college, but merely to have
two years of college instead of
four.
It is thought that the great
number of junior colleges in California, will greatly facilitate the
workings of the advanced plan at
Leland-Stanford. These junior
colleges include just the first two
years of college and a man who
graduates from one of them will
be eligible to enter Leland-Stanford immediately. It is thought
that probably several of these
junior colleges will spring up in

mbass31
E

Maryland, when Johns Hopkins
adopts its new system.
Dean Ames said that it is impossible to know if Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of LelandStanford developed his idea from
the Johns Hopkins plan or if it
was merely a natural outgrowth
from the junior colleges in California. In either case it reflects
honor upon Dr. Goodnow who
first originated the plan to have
another college adopt it.
The workings of this plan at
Johns Hopkins will be much more
elaborate and comprehensive than
at Leland-Stanford. This will he
the case since at Leland-Stanford
they are going to limit their college, while we intend to expand
ours. Their plan will merely make
a two-year college from a fouryear one, while the plan here will
change a college to a great university.

DR. EDMUNDS LEAVES TO
TAKE UP NEW WORK
IN NEW YORK

Icelandic Play Next
On Playshop Program

Former Hopkins Provost Will Tour
"The Hraun Farm" by Johann

Now that the Fiftieth Anniversary Celebration is a memory, the
most faithful of all is leaving us.
No one was ever more faithful to
a task than Dr. Edmunds, who,
since 1924, had been arranging the
greatest celebration that this University has ever held. Tonight he
leaves for New York City, where
he takes up his work with Lingnan
University. For twenty years he
had been associated with that University, and thought he had severed
for all time official connections with
them when he came to Hopkins.
But a greater duty calls Dr. Edmunds back to work where he had
so long worked, and he must go.
Will Tour Country

Contrary to reports published in
the NEWS-LETTER, Dr. Edmunds is
not going to China, or at least has
no present intention of so doing.
Until the end of the present scholastic year, Dr. Edmunds is going to
travel around this country in the
interests of Lingnan.
To quote Dr. Edmunds: "I have
enjoyed my work here, it has been
interesting and everyone has cooperated with me so willingly. I
am sorry to leave, but a greater
duty calls. The work will be left in
most capable hands, however, for
Dr. Ames is the one man I know
who can thoroughly carry out the
work.
Enjoyed Work

"The most pleasant thought I
shall take with me is the knowledge
that the alumni and friends of this
University have now the best spirit
they have ever had. But all I can
say is that my work was interesting
and enjoyable and that I'm sorry
to go."
• Dr. Edmunds is not half so sorry
to leave as his friends are to see
him go. He has been a hard and
efficient worker, a pleasant coworker, and a thorough gentleman
in all his dealings. And that is the
highest praise to give.
Results Evident

The results of the Fiftieth Anniversary Celebration show the earnestness with which Dr. Edmunds
applied himself. The grand total of
gifts and pledges to the Fund, as
of October 5, was $5,997,996.54.
The forty-seven classes of graduates in the College of Arts and Sciences gave $331,195.57, led by the
class of 1884 with $58,400. The
graduate school gave $232,719.13,
the Political Economy Department
giving $58,000 of that amount. The
Medical School classes gave $106,085 which brought the University
total to $807,674. Individual alumni gave $597,579, which with other
gifts, made up the total.

Hopkins'-Fifth Game
May Not Be Held
Because of the 'financial loss incurred in the promoting of last
year's Hopkins-Fifth Regiment
games, it is very doubtful whether
the University athletic authorities
will participate in the meet this
year.
Last year the armory contest
was a complete ,financial failure,
due to the total lack of support
from either the local sporting public or the Hopkins undergraduate
body. Thirteen colleges, twentyseven high schools and nine athletic clubs participated. Charlie
Hoff, the Norwegian star, Willie
Plant and Herb Myer were booked
as feature stars.
In place of the usual HopkinsFifth Regiment games there is a
possibility that an interscholastic
meet will be sponsored by the Jay
athletic authorities. The armory
would be used for the event but
no connection will exist between
the Hopkins and the Fifth Regiment athletic departments.

JONES STARS FOR ORANGE
Second String End Gains 250 Yards
and Scores Three Touchdowns

A revamped Hopkins eleven
fought back to a revamped Syracuse team on the New Yorkers'
field, and made a highly creditable
showing last Saturday. The score
was 31-0.
Syracuse, with eight men on
the injured list, used many substitutes. The Jay team was also
shifted from last week's list.
New Jay Lineup

Kaplan took the place of Pin dell
in the backfield and Ciscle replaced
Strader at center. Jackson was
substituted for Lyons when the
latter suflered what was at first
feared to be a serious concussion
of the brain. Graduate Manager
Keyes declared that "Bobby" was
all right late Sunday night.
Jones Orange Star

The most brilliant player in the
game was Jones, Orange signal
caller, who was promoted from
second string end. Jones gained
a total of over 250 yards himself
and scored three touchdowns. At
the start of the second half he ran
the ball back 80 yards from kickoff for a touchdown.
Although Syracuse scored 12
points in the first period of each
half, the Jays showed their fight
by holding them in the second and
fourth quarters. The Orange was
held scoreless in the second frame

MUCH MATERIAL FOR STUDY
In the Botanical Laboratories in
Gilman Hall three graduate students and the head of the department are still busy studying specimens of tropical flora brought
back from Jamaica as the result
of a scientific expedition there last
summer.
The expedition included members of the Department of Botany
at the johns Hopkins as well as
several noted botanists from other
institutions. The party was led
by Dr. Duncan S. Johnson, head
of the Department of Botany at
Hopkins. Dr. W. R. Maxon, fern
specialist at the Smithsonian Museum in Washington, a member
of the expedition, collected some
two thousand specimens of ferns

IS THE OLD FIGHT PASSING?
A few weeks ago, the NEWS-LETTER commented editorially
upon the lack of spirit at football games. At that time the year
had just begun, freshmen were absolutely green, and upper classmen had not yet got back in the traces. It was only natural that
during the first week all types of organization should be at sixes
and sevens. We contented ourselves, therefore, with simply calling attention to the poor spirit, since in the past such

a

comment,

coupled with the settling influence exerted by the passage of a
week or two, has always been all that was necessary to set things
going right.
This year we were wrong; it has not been sufficient. Three
home games have been played. At no time have more than four
hundred and fifty students been present; out of the eight hundred
only slightly more than six hundred have procured their Athletic
Association tickets.
Support of the team, especially as evidenced by cheering at
games, has lagged all year; and in the Loyola game, when it was
needed most, it reached its lowest ebb.

While the eleven was

sliding around in the mud, fighting its hardest against an opponent of totally unexpected strength, what support did it get
from the stands?

Not much. The cheering section, small as

it is, was not completely filled. Those who were there, huddled
around a hurriedly summoned remnant of the band, save for a
few yells which were not any too good, sat in dejected silence.
That was not an inspiring sight to the men on the field, who were
doing their best and taking a bad beating in the bargain; nor
was it encouraging to any of those interested in football at Hopkins.
"Playing the game for the game's sake," and not "a winner
at any cost," may be only poses at some institutions. At Hopkins this spirit has been genuine, and in it lies the strength and
value of athletics at the University. An incident like the spirit
at the Loyola game may be an indication that the old Hopkins
standards of amateurism and sturdy support are changing. We
hope, however, that it was only an accident, springing from some
other cause.
Three more home games, including the two biggest, remain.
At these three games we will have a chance to see whether or not
the old Hopkins fight is passing.

Frosh Debaters
At a meeting of the candidates
for the freshman debating team
on last Wednesday, Dr. French
picked the men who will represent

based on the quality of speeches
that each candidate prepared on
either side of the question, "Resolved, That the non-athletic activities in American colleges constitute an unwise use of the student's time."
There was an exceedingly poor
representation—only four members of the class being present.
The team finally chosen consisted
of Milton Blumenfeld, chairman,
Paul Spear, Paul Cordish, and
Leroy London, alternate.

LELAND STANFORD ADOPTS NEW
PLAN IN MODIFIED FORM
Leland-Stanford University has
decided to follow the lead of
Johns Hopkins and do away with
the first two years of undergraduate work. Dean Ames, in commenting on this step, said that the
Leland-Stanford plan would differ
from Johns Hopkins' in that Leland-Stanford does not plan to
make a graduate university out of
their college, but merely to have
two years of college instead of
four.
It is thought that the great
number of junior colleges in California, will greatly facilitate the
workings of the advanced plan at
Leland-Stanford. These junior
colleges include just the first two
years of college and a man who
graduates from one of them will
be eligible to enter Leland-Stanford immediately. It is thought
that probably several of these
junior colleges will spring up in

mbass31
E

Maryland, when Johns Hopkins
adopts its new system.
Dean Ames said that it is impossible to know if Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of LelandStanford developed his idea from
the Johns Hopkins plan or if it
was merely a natural outgrowth
from the junior colleges in California. In either case it reflects
honor upon Dr. Goodnow who
first originated the plan to have
another college adopt it.
The workings of this plan at
Johns Hopkins will be much more
elaborate and comprehensive than
at Leland-Stanford. This will he
the case since at Leland-Stanford
they are going to limit their college, while we intend to expand
ours. Their plan will merely make
a two-year college from a fouryear one, while the plan here will
change a college to a great university.

Now that the Fiftieth Anniversary Celebration is a memory, the
most faithful of all is leaving us.
No one was ever more faithful to
a task than Dr. Edmunds, who,
since 1924, had been arranging the
greatest celebration that this University has ever held. Tonight he
leaves for New York City, where
he takes up his work with Lingnan
University. For twenty years he
had been associated with that University, and thought he had severed
for all time official connections with
them when he came to Hopkins.
But a greater duty calls Dr. Edmunds back to work where he had
so long worked, and he must go.
Will Tour Country

Contrary to reports published in
the NEWS-LETTER, Dr. Edmunds is
not going to China, or at least has
no present intention of so doing.
Until the end of the present scholastic year, Dr. Edmunds is going to
travel around this country in the
interests of Lingnan.
To quote Dr. Edmunds: "I have
enjoyed my work here, it has been
interesting and everyone has cooperated with me so willingly. I
am sorry to leave, but a greater
duty calls. The work will be left in
most capable hands, however, for
Dr. Ames is the one man I know
who can thoroughly carry out the
work.
Enjoyed Work

"The most pleasant thought I
shall take with me is the knowledge
that the alumni and friends of this
University have now the best spirit
they have ever had. But all I can
say is that my work was interesting
and enjoyable and that I'm sorry
to go."
• Dr. Edmunds is not half so sorry
to leave as his friends are to see
him go. He has been a hard and
efficient worker, a pleasant coworker, and a thorough gentleman
in all his dealings. And that is the
highest praise to give.
Results Evident

The results of the Fiftieth Anniversary Celebration show the earnestness with which Dr. Edmunds
applied himself. The grand total of
gifts and pledges to the Fund, as
of October 5, was $5,997,996.54.
The forty-seven classes of graduates in the College of Arts and Sciences gave $331,195.57, led by the
class of 1884 with $58,400. The
graduate school gave $232,719.13,
the Political Economy Department
giving $58,000 of that amount. The
Medical School classes gave $106,085 which brought the University
total to $807,674. Individual alumni gave $597,579, which with other
gifts, made up the total.
